SubTopics: Understand that all rational numbers can be written as fractions or decimal numbers that terminate or repeat.
Content: Select the THREE rational numbers.

SubTopics: Write and/or solve two-step equations of the form px + q = r and p(x + q) = r, where p, q and r are rational numbers, and interpret the meaning of the solution in the context of the problem.
Content: Lamar has a container filled with nickels that have a value of $51.45. He has 4 other identical containers with nickels. Of the 4 other identical containers,

:ibox:• 2 of them are full,
• 1 of them is 3/4 full, and
• 1 of them is 1/2 full.
Lamar estimates that the total value of all 5 containers of nickels is approximately $250. Which statement BEST explains why Lamar’s estimate is likely an overestimate or an underestimate?

A.Choice: Lamar’s estimate is likely an underestimate because 5 × $51 = $255.

B.Choice: Lamar’s estimate is likely an underestimate because it is likely that at least one of the other 2 full containers contains more than $51.45.

C.Choice: Lamar’s estimate is likely an overestimate because he has just over 4 full containers, and 4 × $50 = $200.

D.Choice: Lamar’s estimate is likely an overestimate because it is doubtful that the other full containers are worth exactly $51.45.

SubTopics: Interpret products and quotients of rational numbers by describing real-world contexts.
Content: A recipe calls for 2 1/3 cups of flour. Jane needs to make only half of the recipe. Which expression could Jane use to calculate the number of cups of flour she needs?

SubTopics: Identify and/or compute the constant of proportionality (unit rate).
Content: Emanuel is planting trees along a new city sidewalk. He plants the same number of trees on each city block. After 3 blocks, he has planted 15 trees. After 5 blocks, he has planted 25 trees. At what rate is Emanuel planting trees?

SubTopics: Determine the distance between two rational numbers on the number line is the absolute value of their difference.
Content: Diego does a science experiment. In the experiment, he mixes two chemicals together and immediately measures the mixture’s temperature. One hour later, he measures the mixture’s temperature again. He records the two temperatures as mand n. The temperature of the mixture immediately after creating it, m, is 1.75°C. The value of |m– n| is 2.25°C.
Plot the minimum AND maximum values for n, the temperature of the mixture one hour later.

SubTopics: Apply properties of operations to simplify and to factor linear algebraic expressions with rational coefficients.
Content: An expression is shown.
Select the TWO expressions that are equivalent to the given expression.

SubTopics: Solve problems involving the four arithmetic operations with rational numbers.
Content: A cat receives 0.15 milliliter of medicine for every 2.5 pounds that it weighs. Tabby is a cat that weighs 9.75 pounds. How much medicine, rounded to the nearest hundredth of a milliliter, should Tabby receive?

SubTopics: Recognize that the graph of any proportional relationship will pass through the origin.
Content: On a softball team, the number of 7th graders is proportional to the number of 8th graders. Which graph could model the relationship between the number of 7th graders and 8th graders on the softball team?

SubTopics: Describe two-dimensional cross sections of pyramids, prisms, cones and cylinders.
Content: A cylinder is sliced parallel to its base, as shown.
problems/MOG7M/media/9a.jpg
Which figure represents the two-dimensional cross section?

SubTopics: Determine probabilities of simple events.
Content: Whenever Hannah turns on her cell phone, it randomly shows a background image from a group of 6 images Hannah has selected. Of the 6 images Hannah has selected,

:ibox:• exactly 2 are of her friends,
• exactly 3 are of her family members, and
• exactly 1 is of her pet dog.
What is the probability that the cell phone shows an image other than the pet dog the next time Hannah turns on her cell phone?

SubTopics: Multiply and divide rational numbers.
Content: What is 4 ÷ (–2.5)?

SubTopics: Explain what a point (x, y) on the graph of a proportional relationship means in terms of the situation.
Content: Christopher has a website. He updates his website the same number of times each week.

:ibox:• After 3 weeks, Christopher had updated his website a total of 12 times.
• After 5 weeks, Christopher had updated his website a total of 20 times.

Christopher makes a graph to show the relationship between the number of weeks that have passed, x, and the number of times he has updated his website, y. Use the numbers below the blank lines to show the coordinates of the point that represents the unit rate, in updates per week, of Christopher’s graph.

SubTopics: Represent the sample space of a compound event.
Content: Chad is putting a frame around a picture. He needs to decide whether he wants the frame to be black or brown. He also needs to decide whether he wants the frame to be made of metal or of wood. Finally, he needs to decide whether he wants the picture covered with glass or with plastic. He makes a list of his options as shown.
Which option did Chad forget to include in his list?

SubTopics: Know and apply the formulas for circumference and area of circles to solve problems.
Content: A sprinkler waters a circular region in Jason’s yard that has a radius of 15 feet. Rounded to the nearest square foot, what is the area of the circular region that is watered by the sprinkler?

SubTopics: Write and/or solve two-step equations of the form px + q = r and p(x + q) = r, where p, q and r are rational numbers, and interpret the meaning of the solution in the context of the problem.
Content: What is the solution to the equation 2(x+ 2.4) = 6.4?

SubTopics: Solve problems involving ratios, rates, percentages and proportional relationships.
Content: A store is offering a 30% discount on shirts. A shirt at the store has an original cost of $25. What is the cost of the shirt, in dollars, after the discount?

SubTopics: Write, solve and/or graph inequalities of the form px + q > r or px + q < r, where p, q and r are rational numbers.
Content: In a mine, 0.6% of all the mined material is copper. The company that runs the mine needs the mine to produce more than 0.81 million tons of copper to make a profit this year. The mine has already produced 0.75 million tons of copper this year. The inequality below represents x, the additional millions of tons of material that need to be mined this year for the mine to make a profit.
Which inequality shows all the possible values of x?

SubTopics: Use data from multiple samples to draw inferences about a population and investigate variability in estimates of the characteristic of interest.
Content: There are 50 tickets in a jar. Each ticket is either red or blue. Jeanette randomly draws 10 tickets from the jar, counts the number of red tickets, and then replaces the tickets. She does this 8 times. The list shows how many red tickets Jeanette drew on each attempt.
What is the BEST estimate for the total number of red tickets in the jar?

SubTopics: Recognize and represent proportional relationships between quantities.
Content: Jamar is buying bottles of juice for his class party. A pack of 12 bottles of juice costs $3.96. Which expression could Jamaruse to determine the cost of 1 bottle of juice?

SubTopics: Understand how to use equivalent expressions to clarify quantities in a problem.
Content: Carter writes the expression 0.25x + 1.75y + 0.25y + 1.5xy. He wants to rewrite the expression by combining like terms. For each pair of terms in the table, select whether they are like terms or not like terms.

SubTopics: Find the volume and surface area of prisms, pyramids and cylinders.
Content: Nina works at a company that makes cylindrical cans. She finds the area of the base of one of the cans and then multiplies that area by the height of the can. What is Nina most likely calculating?

SubTopics: Convert between equivalent forms of the same number.
Content: A club is selling cookies to earn money. The club is going to donate 1/4 of the money to charity and keep the rest. The total cookie sales are $367.20. Which expression could be used to determine the amount of money the club will keep?

SubTopics: Understand that random sampling is used to produce representative samples and support valid inferences.
Content: Arie has a bag that contains 15 yellow marbles, 13 blue marbles, and 22 red marbles. Select the TWO statements that are true when Arie randomly draws 10 marbles from the bag.

A.Choice: She is likely to draw all red marbles.

B.Choice: She is likely to draw more blue marbles than red marbles.

C.Choice: She is likely to draw more red marbles than yellow marbles.

D.Choice: She is likely to draw about the same number of yellow and blue marbles.

E.Choice: She is likely to draw more red marbles than yellow and blue marbles combined.

SubTopics: Write and/or solve equations of the form x+p = q and px = q in which p and q are rational numbers.
Content: Li put $75 into his savings account. The money was 1/3 of his paycheck. Which equation could be used to find the amount of money, p, in dollars, on his paycheck?

SubTopics: Explain what a point (x, y) on the graph of a proportional relationship means in terms of the situation.
Content: Charlie is charging his tablet. The graph shows how long it takes for his tablet to charge.
problems/MOG7M/media/25a.jpg
Which statement about the ordered pair (5, 25) is true?

A.Choice: It takes 5 minutes to charge 25 tablets.

B.Choice: It takes 25 minutes to charge 5 tablets.

C.Choice: It takes 5 minutes to charge 1 tablet to 25%.

D.Choice: It takes 25 minutes to charge 1 tablet to 5%.

SubTopics: Write, solve and/or graph inequalities of the form px + q > r or px + q < r, where p, q and r are rational numbers.
Content: An inequality is shown.
What is the solution to the inequality?

SubTopics: Write, solve and/or graph inequalities of the form px + q > r or px + q < r, where p, q and r are rational numbers.
Content: An expression is shown.
Which expression is equivalent to the given expression?

SubTopics: Interpret sums and differences of rational numbers.
Content: Linda ate 1/8 of a batch of cornbread. Peter ate some cornbread so that there is 2/3 of the batch remaining. What fraction of the batch of cornbread did Peter eat?

SubTopics: Identify and/or compute the constant of proportionality (unit rate).
Content: A proportional relationship is shown.
problems/MOG7M/media/29a.jpg
What is the constant of proportionality?

SubTopics: Write and/or solve two-step equations of the form px + q = r and p(x + q) = r, where p, q and r are rational numbers, and interpret the meaning of the solution in the context of the problem.
Content: Jorge wants to buy his father a gift that costs $32. He has already saved $18 for the gift. Jorge saves the same amount of money each week for the next 4 weeks. How much money, in dollars, will Jorge have to save each week to have exactly enough money to buy his father the gift?

SubTopics: Compare theoretical and experimental probabilities.
Content: Lily tosses a fair coin in the air 20 times and records the results. The coin lands with the tails side up in 12 of the 20 trials. Which statement about Lily’s trials is correct?

A.Choice: The theoretical probability is 50%, because at least 50% of Lily’s coin tosses landed with the tails side up.

B.Choice: The theoretical probability of landing with the tails side up is 12/20 = 60%, because that is what Lily observed.

C.Choice: The experimental probability is 50%, because at least 50% of Lily’s coin tosses landed with the tails side up.

D.Choice: The experimental probability of landing with the tails side up is 12/20 = 60%, because that is what Lily observed.

SubTopics: Use angle properties to write and solve equations for an unknown angle.
Content: Lines m and n are shown.
problems/MOG7M/media/32a.jpg
Angle A measures 38°. What is the measure, in degrees, of angle B?

SubTopics: Add and subtract rational numbers.
Content: Louis went to a movie with $20.00. The ticket cost $9.50, and he spent $2.75 on snacks. How much money did Louis have left over?

SubTopics: Solve problems involving ratios, rates, percentages and proportional relationships.
Content: Julia uses a scale to weigh three identical stacks of coins.

:ibox:• The scale has a maximum percent error of 3%.
• The scale says the weight of the first stack of coins is 10.0 ounces.
• The scale says the weight of the second stack of coins is 10.3 ounces.
Rounded to the nearest tenth of an ounce, what is the greatest possible amount that the scale could say for the weight of the third stack of coins?

SubTopics: Analyze different data distributions using statistical measures.
Content: Class X and class Y each have 20 students. They each keep track of the number of books each student reads in one month. The mean number of books read by the students in class X is 4.2 books. The mean number of books read by the students in class Y is 3.8 books. Select the TWO statements that are true.

A.Choice: Every student in class X read more books than any student in class Y.

B.Choice: The students in class X like reading more than the students in class Y.

C.Choice: The students in class X read longer books than the students in class Y.

D.Choice: On average, the students in class X read more books than the students in class Y.

E.Choice: The total number of books read by class X is more than the total number of books read by class Y.

SubTopics: Solve problems involving scale drawings of real objects and geometric figures, including computing actual lengths and areas from a scale drawing and reproducing the drawing at a different scale.
Content: Ella designs a glass tabletop for a restaurant. She makes the scale drawing shown.
problems/MOG7M/media/36a.jpg

In Ella’s scale drawing, the length of each square on the grid represents 12 inches. Make a new scale drawing of Ella’s tabletop in which the length of each square on the grid represents 6 inches. The plotted point in Ella’s new scale drawing should correspond to the plotted point in Ella’s original scale drawing.

SubTopics: Convert a rational number to a decimal.
Content: Chelsea buys a bag of apples. In the bag, 8/11 of the apples are green. Which number could also represent the portion of the apples in the bag that are green?

SubTopics: Determine if provided constraints will create a unique triangle through construction.
Content: A triangle has sides that are 4 units, 6 units, and m units long. Select the TWO numbers that are possible values of m.

SubTopics: Recognize and represent proportional relationships between quantities.
Content: Sophia earned $18 for working 2 1/4 hours. How much did she earn per hour?

SubTopics: Understand how to use equivalent expressions to clarify quantities in a problem.
Content: A library keeps track of the number of overdue items at the end of each month.

:ibox:• At the end of April, there were x overdue items.
• At the end of May, the number of overdue items was 3% less than the number of overdue items at the end of April.

The expression x – 0.03x represents the number of overdue items at the end of May. Which sentence BEST explains how to simplify the expression that represents the number of overdue items at the end of May?

A.Choice: Combine x and 0.03x, since they are like terms, by canceling out the x.

B.Choice: Combine x and 0.03x, since they are like terms, by subtracting 1 – 0.03 to find the new coefficient.

C.Choice: Factor out an x, since it appears in both terms, leaving 1 in the first term and 0.03xin the second term.

D.Choice: Factor out an x, since it appears in both terms, eliminating the first term and leaving 0.03 in the second term.

SubTopics: Explain what a point (x, y) on the graph of a proportional relationship means in terms of the situation.
Content: The graph shows the number of hours it takes to assemble several items at a shipping warehouse.
problems/MOG7M/media/41a.jpg
What does the point (3, 6) represent?

A.Choice: It takes 3 hours to assemble 1 item at the shipping warehouse.

B.Choice: It takes 3 hours to assemble 6 items at the shipping warehouse.

C.Choice: It takes 6 hours to assemble 1 item at the shipping warehouse.

D.Choice: It takes 6 hours to assemble 3 items at the shipping warehouse.

SubTopics: Represent the sample space of a compound event.
Content: Jared sells hot chocolate at football games.

:ibox:• He sells small, medium, and large hot chocolates.
• Each hot chocolate can be ordered with or without whipped cream.
• Each hot chocolate can be ordered with or without peppermint.
Complete the tree diagram to show all the possible ways hot chocolate can be ordered. The options from which to select are shown below the tree diagram.

SubTopics: Convert between equivalent forms of the same number.
Content: Hector has 3/4 hour to spend completing his homework. He wants to spend 1/3 of his time on math homework, 10 minutes of his time on reading homework, and the remaining time on science homework. How much time, in MINUTES, does Hector have to spend on his science homework?

SubTopics: Determine when two quantities are in a proportional relationship.
Content: Gary has a box of pencils. In the box, 7/21 of the pencils have been sharpened. Select the THREE fractions that are proportional to the fraction of sharpened pencils in Gary’s box.

SubTopics: Understand how to use equivalent expressions to clarify quantities in a problem.
Content: Ricardo has a coupon for 25% off his purchase at a craft store. Which expression could Ricardo use to calculate his TOTAL COST when purchasing x dollars of craft supplies?

SubTopics: Describe situations and show that a number and its opposite have a sum of 0 (additive inverses).
Content: Which situation applies an additive inverse to find the total amount of money?

B.Choice: Dylan found $5 and then found $5 more.

C.Choice: Dylan spent $5 and then gave $3 to a friend.

D.Choice: Dylan found $5 and then kept the money in his pocket.

SubTopics: Analyze proportional relationships and use them to solve problems.
Content: Emma is buying a shirt for each member of her school’s spirit club. There are 300 students in her school, and 20% of the students are members of the spirit club. Emma can buy the shirts from either Company A or Company B. The costs for buying different numbers of shirts are shown in the table for Company A and in the graph for Company B.
problems/MOG7M/media/47a.jpg
problems/MOG7M/media/47b.jpg
Which company gives Emma the better deal? Show or explain your reasoning.
Be sure to include the total cost, in dollars, for buying the shirts from each company.
Company A: :FR-1:
Company B: :FR-2:

SubTopics: Analyze proportional relationships and use them to solve problems.
Content: Reagan and Jordan want to purchase a new bed for their dog. All beds at Paul’s Pets are 50% off. While they are shopping, the store announces a special sale for an additional 20% off the discounted price for all items. The bed Reagan and Jordan want to purchase costs $45 before any discounts are applied.
Reagan claims that pet beds are now 70% off. Jordan disagrees and claims that the total discount is not 70%. Who is correct? Provide mathematical evidence for your reasoning.
Be sure to include the final cost of the bed for Reagan’s claim.
